comments.commentBody: Not when other countries have dramatically fewer gun deaths of all kinds than we have.  Just because in this case the AR-15 may have been taken from a victim does not mean that other mass shootings are not made with easily obtainable AR-15's owned by the shooter or a close relative. Furthermore, this man had already used a gun irresponsibly in the past and yet had no trouble obtaining the initially used weapon.

Wake up! This incident is case and point that it's not about the lack of gun control, but rather about the lack of enforcement of existing laws.

This guy faced years and years in prison for what he did in the past, but no charges were pressed against one of his actions and was sentenced to anger management for another.

Soooo true great post.
We have the overall numbers and votes.
We just don't go the polls.
Well, Deuce, I guess what you are saying is that every time there is such a massacre, America is getting what it deserves.  And that is really sad.

This all comes down to us - all those people who can't find the time or interest and care to take one bloody day or a few hours to get to the polls and say "enough is enough" -

Two elected officials just lost their seats because people simply did not care enough to get them to the poll and support the idea of sanity, even the modest attempts to control guns in our country.

Look in your mirror and ask yourself - what is so important in my life that I can't take the time to get out and vote to support the changes that need to be made in my country, state, and city to help bring about the reasonable gun control that we need.

If sensible gun control is being controlled by the NRA and the extreme gun owners in our society - you have no one to blame but yourself if you keep letting them have the control. The forces that insist that the USA should continue to be the Gun Capitol of the World of all developed industrial nations - just keep staying home when your voice and vote would have the power to bring about change.

The powers that be can spend millions of dollars, all it would take to counter their money and control would be for people to get out and vote when it counts. What good does it do if after all these deaths we go through another round of crying and forget about it all in a few days?

How would you feel if one of these innocent victims had been your loved one?

This country belongs to all of us - not only the gun owners of America.
You are missing the point here. The allegation is that the Top Dogs at PSU knew about Sandusky and chose to protect the brand over protecting the victim kids.
Exactly, gershon. The obsession with blame just reinforces the cycle of blindness which reinforces the abuse.

Unfortunately, there are Jerry Sanduskys in every community in America. Pretending it is a Penn State problem only enables the predators in your neighborhood, in your schools, in your churches, in your summer camps, in your Scout groups.  Beware of those who protest loudest.  Remember that Sandusky ran a well-respected charity for at-risk boys. His victims weren't Penn State students. They were children he was supposedly mentoring.

The situation went on for decades. Joe was in charge for decades. Joe created the situation to allow it to go on for decades. Not involved with cover up is not to say he did not facilitate the situation for decades. Stick your head in the sand if you wish Mike, but Joe had his hands dirty. Inaction is still a choice. A choice Joe had to make EVERY DAY for decades.

That said, the whole college football system is likely complicit. How else does one explain why a high-level coach of a national championship team with the former statue of Penn State NOT get hired away - College or NFL?

Mike is correct on both points. Leaders set the tone for their organizations and Joe was the maximum leaders at PSU. The only thing possibly worse then Paterno's response to the allegations was that of the leadership.

The facts are no longer in dispute. Children were abused and this information was brought to a group of men who knew better but decided not to act and thereby helped it continue.

College football is out of control but that's no excuse.

Just to all of the naysayers realize.... The PROSECUTOR of the JERRY SANDUSKY trial said on NATIONAL TV that JOE PATERNO was NOT involved in a cover up. You need to do your homework before you jump on the "kill the Duke lacrosse" style bandwagon.
Well said.
Jason, you clearly don't get it. Did you read the article? Is is about YOU, the misinformed commenters.

Jason it sounds like you just don't want to know. Paterno was a heresay witness to one incident (that he reported) that in the end Sandusky was acquitted of. As much as you want to make this about football, it really has nothing to with it. But you just don't want to know...

Sometimes people just do not want to know. Just like Paterno, Spanier, Curley and others “just didn’t want to know” about Sandusky, there are apparently a great many people associated with Penn State who still “just do not want to know.” Professor Nichols comparison of the Penn State situation to the Duke situation is both outrageous and disingenuous. Unlike Sandusky’s monstrous actions, the “alleged” Duke rape never occurred. Furthermore, unlike various emails among PSU administrators, there was no evidence that suggests any efforts by the Duke administration to hide, soft peddle, or manipulate the situation. At least Nichols is still somewhat connected to reality unlike the delusional Ms. Schmidt, who is “upset that the university has settled with some of the victims.” Her apparent ignorance of what the costs and predictable results of a couple of dozen victim lawsuits would be demonstrates that she should not be allowed to comment on things she knows nothing about. Full disclosure: I earned a graduate degree from Penn State in 1997.

Yo Ira!

Kuroda and Sabathia will likely not "learn" how to throw the heat they threw 10 years ago, as much as they will "learn" how it feels to grow older.

God bless both CC and Kuroda. They give it their all. Just not working out anymore. How much longer is CC signed for? 5 years? Oof.

Unless Sabathia and Kuroda learn how to pitch again no matter how much the team wants to win they cannot do it without them and Sabathia has been a major -  bust all this year and part of last and Kuroda has been figured out he can;t get an out his last 5-6 games
Brian Cashman IS the problem! This is his mess.  Over priced, old,prone to injury etc...
We need Gene Michael back to rebuild our farm system like he did in the '90s.   The Steinbrenners never knew how to do that.

@cjohn836: The only reason those legends were Yankees at the major league level is because when they were coming up, George was suspended for hiring Howie Spira to dig dirt on Dave Winfield. Gene Michael and Bob Watson built the team, and Buck Showalter nurtured them to the playoffs.

And the book on a great farm system was written, and rewritten, many years ago by the Dodgers, who have often had periods where they owned the Rookie of the Year award.

Brian Cashman need to start studying up on the BoSox farm system..who never seem to not have some new talent coming in from somewhere...whereas the Yankees have trapped themselves on a group of Baseball legends who should become their coaches...Will be fascinating to see if they can regroup and come up with some young guns and batters.... but unlikely...Yankees = New Knicks....!

Doug Terry,
The price of oranges is about to skyrocket, thanks to the greening disease that is infecting citrus trees and rendering them incapable of producing useful fruit.

The new book "Scarcity: Why Having Too Little Means So Much" by Sendhil Mullainathan and Eldar Shafir may turn out to be helpful in figuring out poor people's food habits. Also, once one becomes fat, it's difficult to return to slenderness.

I think other recent research showed that some lower-income groups of men prefer plump women, who in turn work at developing the desired appearance (it's too early in the morning to track that down). Perhaps notions of beauty vary with social class.

That said, it's Walmart that places big bags of chips and other high-calorie snacks in the center aisle of the food section.

Doug Terry, handsomeness is in the eye of the beholder. i believe that in more affluent brackets, ongoing sexual attractiveness (in a youthful manner, representing independence) is considered to be something to be striving for. In less affluent brackets, the transition to obvious 'mom-ness' is something to be valued and lauded, representing comfort, caring and responsibility for others. And, thinness has often been associated with want, threatened fertility and lack of emotional sustenance in many eras/cultures. Just, in this media saturated culture, thinness is now equated with superior control, life-planning, leisure, and glamour. If you are thin now, you prove that you are not afraid of when you will eat again. You prove you have enough time not worried about making ends meet to sculpt your body. And, you prove that you are in possession of yourself - erroneously, of course. Most importantly, you prove that you can always move on; you are not soft. Therefore, you are desirable to affluent men who need to feel that they are coupled with a rare and elusive feminine commodity that builds their life portfolio. And, life will never be de-sexualized. It will always be sleek, handsome and designed.

We've erroneously equated big with exceptional. Texas comes to mind. Now the folks who control big food, big oil, big banks and big pharma want to belittle big government, in part at least to stem any impediments to their exponential growth. I can just see hordes of 50 foot tall women and giant Michelin men parading around, yelling "Honey! I shrunk the president!". Fortunately, for now, Mr. Christie will not attain the presidency by winning a Sumo wrestling competition.
On another note, I'm surprised Doug Terry gets away with addressing large posteriors, meager incomes and small I.Q.'s, even though the Times claims there are no P.C. sensors for these comments.

I live in a beach town where the beach people tend to be Hamptons-slender. I assume that there's intense social pressure to be thin. The Publix supermarket closest to the beach is full of healthy-looking people.

Inland, the customers at Target average a bit plumper. I've seen an electronic cart in use at Target only once, and that was a bit of a joyride by a curious young foreigner. Across the street from Target at Walmart, the customers often average far heavier, and weight-related disability is on display, except maybe late at night. As a further complication, Walmart customers vary quite a lot by time of day and day of week. Mornings tend to be for retirees. We don't have Costco anywhere near, nor an Aldi grocery store.

I wish Paul Fussell were still around to write a sequel to his "Class: A Guide Through the American Status System," perhaps in collaboration with someone in the public health field or an obesity researcher.

If a consumer has no disposable cash but owns an iPhone 4/4s, he can trade it in at an Apple Store for a credit greater than the $99 up-front price of buying a 5c.  At that point, the consumer will have a new 5c iPhone, the same monthly bill (ATT, Verizon, etc.) and a $50-$100 credit with Apple.

Apple sold a huge number of of 4s's two years ago, and it seems like most of those buyers would now be ready for a free trade-in/upgrade --- either to 5c's (for cash-strapped consumers) or 5s's (others).

Personally, I like the more subtle colors of the 5s, and its technology enhancements (faster processor speed, better camera, fingerprint recognition) are well worth the $100 price difference (over the 5c).
If there's a nickel - there's a fight.
The more money you've got the more there is for your "grieving" relatives to fight over.

Recurring baseball hallucinations and delusions of grandeur really require professional psychiatric care in order for sanity and reason to re-enter the conscious and sub-conscious mind.

The Yankees need help pretty badly.
Hideous comes to mind.

This just shows that you can do something for 20 years, and lose everything that you had worked for over one result. Don had probably inspired many people with his lifting records,but now he has lost it all. People do not look at him the same now because his testosterone levels were too high. I'm not saying if it is right or wrong, but he is labeled as a cheater now. For the rest of his life he will be known as a cheater, which is a shame because he did not do anything different then he had been for the past 20 years.

I think many people like to simplify how to help people by saying "give a hand up, not a hand out". In reality, I don't think addressing complex social problems is as simple as that. People like to claim that the B1G1 model has the potential to undermine markets. While I don't doubt this is the case in some scenarios, I would love to see convincing evidence this is the case with companies such as TOMS.  J-PAL recently ran an experiment in Africa testing which was more effective, handing out bed nets for free, or making people pay for them (they had 10 different prices from full priced to almost completely subsidized). They found that even requiring people to pay a fraction of market price, drastically reduced the chances they would buy one. People had the same proper usage rates of bed nets across all conditions. They also found that people who were given free bed nets were actually more likely to buy one in the future. Point is, sometimes giving something out for free is the most effective and efficient solution. We need more evidence before we can start making conclusions about the B1G1 model.
How is fasting 1-2 days a week not living in semi-starvation?

@rachel,

Many thousands of people all over the world are controlling their weight by cutting back calories to 25% of their usual on 2 non-consecutive days of the week, creating a weekly calorie deficit of about a pound. It's called the 5:2 eating plan--nothing to buy, no meetings, no dues to pay. It's not popular with diet gurus. But my doctor approves. I've lost 10 pounds, only 4 more to go to my goal.

You can read about it at http://www.52fastdiet.co.uk/ .

Non of us on the plan are starving or even semi-starving. The weight loss is sustainable because when we are hungry on a restricted day, we know that we can eat our regular diet tomorrow.

Semi-starvation to my mind describes "sensible" diets -- restricting calories, weighing, portioning, 24/7 counting and obsessing and scheming. Even low-carb, which involves far less counting and generates far less actual raw hunger, can be a pretty ascetic and joyless way to live.

Breakfast-sized meal not taken till lunchtime and then a smallish dinner, two days a week? That, I can handle. It's not actual fasting as in 24 hours without food, just a 500-600 calorie day. Plain coffee for breakfast, a lentil soup or an egg and a piece of fruit for lunch, and a smallish and consciously healthful dinner -- fish and broccoli, vegetable stew, or whatever. Perhaps a little less than usual or without the carb you'd normally have. The other five days a week: no counting, no calculating, no rule-chanting, no obsessive attention.

And in this corner, our evolutionary counterbalance to the ever present possibility of starvation (all too likely before Costco); the genetic demand for engorgement when possible. The simple remedy for Costco remorse: fasting on Mondays, possibly even also Tuesdays, as may be required. No calorie counting, no living in semi-starvation, no second guessing. Simple; no?

Skimming both the article and the comments, I saw only a brief reference to the most important function of the Flight Attendants: SAFETY! They train rigorously and are tested in various simulations, including preparing for emergency landings, "ditching" into water, egressing after an emergency landing, smoke inside the fuselage, loss of pressurization, etc.

Consider all that the next time they do the safety briefing before takeoff.

I'm at a loss to understand there are people who want to believe the Assad government is innocent of gassing his own people, like RLS.   The Rebels do not have surface to surface missiles developed to carry Sarin, nor access or capability to make Sarin gas of the quality the report from the UN spoke of.  The President of Iran said it was Syria and Human Rights Watch said it was Syria, the BBC reports have paralleled this as well.  Our own intelligence has not been refuted by any other intelligence.  We have only the dismissal of all these reports by President Putin.  But we have people wanting to believe something else.  It is more a supposition built on a faith, maybe an apprehension caused by Iraq or an ideology, but not the evidence and views of those who already have skin in the game.  We have now what we didn't have then, the French wanted us to go a bit further, but in a rush of judgment with deceit of Congress and the people Bush committed a war crime(s).  Yet we have evidence that one has been committed by the government of Syria and diplomacy, so far, has won the day, but to say it was the Rebels is to be deceptive to others.
RLS, I think that has now been accomplished.

Ken Wood. Agreed, but there is a little more than "trust me" here. Assad gassed children, it is clear.  If the argument is "it is none of our business", that's a different matter. But if we cannot turn away from an act like this, we are past the "trust me" phase.

I'm astonished at the number of commenters here who seem convinced (on the basis of no apparent evidence) that the rebels are to blame for the chemical attacks and that the Assad regime is being persecuted by the American media. I can only surmise that many of them are the same people whose hearts were warmed by the wisdom and goodwill of the Putin op-ed piece.

http://brown-moses.blogspot.com/2013/09/who-was-responsible-for-august-2...
"One thing that must be stressed, is that the UMLACA is a munition that's never been seen in any other conflict, and it's origins are somewhat of a mystery. This has led some people to claim the munition could have been constructed by the opposition, and one popular video shows what's claimed to be a chemical munition being used by the opposition, with some even claimed it's the UMLACA, even though it's clearly a totally different design."

This either has been manufactured for this particular conflict, or has been manufactured earlier but kept very obscure, perhaps for reasons of plausible deniability.

As for the 140mm, see the same article; a lot of rebel-controlled weapon systems ARE known, including very specific rocket artillery types, and no 140mm systems are among them.

There was considerable proof that the rebels did it previously in Khan al-Asal. Obama's obstruction of UN investigations there has done little to strengthen the case that the government did it.

The discussion in the US was whether the US should bomb Syria. In that case strict criteria for evidence should be used. Accidentally bombing the wrong side because you were to lazy to check diligently is plain murder.

President Assad has done one deed for which he must be remembered: He ratified the ban on CBW's. Such action may prove the turning point in human history, whereby all UN Member Nations must do the same, to be counted as "civilized" governments deserving of UN responsibilities & protections.
He has granted military authority to deploy his arsenal of missiles to the Iranian controlled Hezbollah-who fight for Assad-against their Lebanese governments strict "disengagement" policy. Iran's IRG forces of 4,000 plus soldiers, also have control of those missile systems-that are supplied & designed by Russia & Iran.
The UN should demand a duty roster for 8-21-13, so that culpability might be better determined.
The purpose of CBW's is mass murder & cannot be targeted to strike only combatants. If the families, medical providers & other key personnel can be slaughtered, than the effectiveness of CBW's as a terror tactic is successful. Combatants may take excessive chances, having lost all the people that they individually live for, & willingly fight to their deaths, regardless of their effectiveness. The demoralization of such a horriffic type of weapon cannot be overstated. The bodies remain intact, a measure of horror beyond comprehension. A nuclear arsenal simply incenerates-obliterates all evidence of human suffering.
Lebanon has relinquished control of Hezbollah, a functional seperate nation,with seperate taxation, full military-to Iran. A terrorist coup.

Yuri, we really do not know who did it. He is what he is. People lie with statistics, show samples that fit their models, create scenarios that point in one direction or other to suit them--just like you say. Since, we do not know who did it and who ordered this, where these chemicals really came from---there is no trail leading back to the source...we have to let it be. I do not care for Assad or any of his cronies, I simply am NOT INTERESTED in the USA going there.

Invariably people who question Assad's culpability are also people who are philosophically on "his" side. Which points to an age old human folly of presenting arguments that fit your narrative. We, as humans, lack honesty and integrity to simply state that "Yes he did it, and I still support him". We like things to be all black or white and when it gets to gray, we fib, deflect, pontificate, and just about anything else to support our point of view.

In fact, he did do it. He is a nasty dictator who is clinging to power. And it is also a fact that many who militarily oppose him are crazed fundamentalists who are capable of the same. Why can't we call it like it is?
If your comment shows anything, it's that you're prone to hyperbole.

If this chemical weapon attack and the subsequent investigation showed anything, it showed the the UN is hapless, the Administration is gutless and the Russians and the Chinese are shameless.

Is that really news?

That's funny, because I read on the Washington Post it was the shotgun bought in VA. I guess it's just like CT where they didn't know what kind of gun it actually was. So, I'm not sure what kind of insider information you have saying the AR-15 was bought in VA, (probably Piers Morgan eye roll) but that doesn't matter because facts don't really matter for you to push your agenda. I guess they don't teach reading in Baltimore...

No, we don't teach geography in schools anymore. There's so many internet BA's that are ready and willing to do so.

I am an NRA member and strong 2nd amendment guy. Having said that, I do support that idea. Loonies and nuts should not own guns, or drive cars, or be walking around freely for that matter. The two most destructive incidents to occur in America in the last 40 years, the World trade Center bldgs and Oklahoma City, both happened w/out a single bullet being fired. We have 240 million guns in America. If guns were the problem you'd have 10,000 being shot daily in each of our major cities. We have a serious mental health crisis. Last night many were raped, or beaten, or carjacked but do we worry about that? How many children were sodomized or raped last night? Probably in the thousands. Do we worry about that. No, sadly we don't.  The gun issue is a fear of who will do the policing. I for one do not want Hillary Clinton, or George Soros, or Al Gore making that determination for me. The left has shown that they cannot be trusted to do anything right. They have created this problem by educating a world of self centered narcissists. When they grow up and realize that they are not the center of the universe they have no God to turn to, no family support, and the government is a poor substitute for both. They too often explode. As sad as this incident is, a much bigger problem is the everyday rapes, and muggings, and carjackings that go on which occur daily and in much, much greater frequency than these shootings.

He had secret clearance despite the mental issues.I think this fact is more important than the fact he had access to guns. Maybe we should look at DOD's sscreening procedures more so than anti-gun laws.

The lunatics committing these crimes are both impulsive and methodical. If their background check (that already exists) bars them from getting one legally, or a waiting period (prevalent in many areas) interferes with their plans, do you honestly believe they just go home and forget about it??

Notwithstanding military sales, the illegal gun trade far exceeds the legal one in this country and around the world.

Mass shooting have been occurring more often and innocent people are dying. Some might say that it has nothing to due with the guns that killed these people and that it was the person who pulled the trigger. Which I agree is very true. The shooters of these killing sprees have all experienced mental disorders or have had violent behaviors in the past but yet they are still able to go and buy a semi-automatic gun. Gun control laws should be stricter and an intense background check should be made and a waiting period should be established. This could decrease the amount of mass shootings and prevent guns be handled by the wrong person.

I'm going to go out on a limb here and say that anyone who walked outside of their apartment and shot the tires out of a car, and was arrested and prosecuted for said crime, likely couldn't legally own a gun.

So, not following your argument, if you have one at all.

Edgar:
If you are mentally ill, you should not be out in public.
If you are not out in public you cannot walk into a gun shop.
If you cannot walk into a gun shop you don't need a background check.

Stop releasing the mentally ill (and the sexual predators) back into the general population. When US policy stops peopling my neighborhood with criminals and the mentally ill, I can stop being a warden with a gun.

Here in NY you can get online maps of the criminals in your neighborhood. There are more added every month. The idea is that you avoid those areas, but since those people are not locked in it means they can come into the library, the schools, and my yard at will.

We ARE organized to keep people safe. It is called imprisonment. The cells are full, so the trend it to turn neighborhoods into prisons. Until that stops, guns in the hands of lawful citizens are a necessity.

No one is putting guns in anyone's hand.  The nutcases seek them out.  Gun bans only affect the law abiding; serving only as a speed bump to the maniacs who can, and will ALWAYS get what they want by means OUTSIDE the law.

I am so tired of all the defenders of the 2nd Amendment who keep saying no one with mental illness should own a gun and then proceed to fight background checks or any kind of control.  They defend some antiquated idea against the lives of children and adults who only wished to go to school the next day or to go to work safely.  We can't get organized to keep everyone safe, but there are people who can sure get organized to put more guns into anyone's hands.
Yes it is it's on the front page

"Why is there so much Violence in the World, today?"

Apparently, in this country at least, because there are so many guns.
